container-title: Homo Ludens: A Study of the Play Element in Culture
note: emphasis original.
title: For Johan Huizinga, whose foundational study Homo Ludens is the basis of all cultural and literary game study, games are either “a contest for something or a representation of something

note: Huizinga advocates the higher aesthetic, ethical, and creative cultural purpose of play, although at times he qualifies its seriousness.
title: Nearly all game scholars believe that playing games serves some sort of purpose: Brian Sutton-Smith, for example, argues that people “play to let off steam, and to learn something
and Juul maintains that playing games is “fundamentally a learning experience
but not all agree that play is meaningful, most notably Roger Caillois, who maintains that play is “without consequence for real life
On the purpose of play in a variety of humanities-based disciplines and Huizinga’s concept of the meaningfulness of play, see especially Warren Motte, Playtexts: Ludics in Contemporary Literature

The Consistorio de Barcelona, established in 1393 by Joan I to teach the Gay Science of the troubadours, mirrored the toulousian Consistori del Gay Saber. In its Arte de Trovar, Enrique de Villena—who had been charged with the task of reforming the consistory during the reign of Fernando de Antequera (1412–1416)—offers an account of the events that lead to its foundation. Juan II of Castille and Á lvaro de Luna would often participate in and win the contests

John Gornall indicates that many invenciones, recorded during the tournaments of the fifteenth century, present some significant configurations that suggest an origin in the tournaments themselves. See Gornall, “Invenciones from Tournaments to Cancionero: Some Significant Patterns?

Roland Barthes opposes the readerly text—a text that insists on a fixed meaning—to the writerly text: “The writerly (scriptible) text is a perpetual present, upon which no consequent language (which would inevitably make it past) can be superimposed; the writerly text is ourselves writing, before the infinite play of the world (the world as function) is traversed, intersected, stopped, plasticized by some singular system (Ideology, Genus, Criticism) which reduces the plurality of entrances, the opening of networks, the infinity of languages
